headline: Avocado and Grapefruit Salad with Aji Panca Vinaigrette Recipe
description: Aji panca's light fruitiness pairs well with assertive, aromatic grapefruit and buttery avocadoâ€”it plays off their best attributes and brings them closer together. Though this a decidedly winter salad, it feels summery, and it'd be the perfect accompaniment for a winter grill fest-turned-taco night. Or dice the fruit fine and pile it on toast for breakfast. Yes, you'll need to segment your grapefruit for this, but once you get a little practice it's easy and kind of fun. If you buy an extra couple practice grapefruit you'll be a pro by serving time.
name: Avocado and Grapefruit Salad with Aji Panca Vinaigrette Recipe
recipeIngredient: 2 large ruby grapefruits, cut into segments, juice reserved
2 ripe Hass avocados, cut in half and sliced 1/4 inch thick
4-6 tablespoons red onion, diced fine, divided
4 teaspoons aji panca (or pasilla chile), ground (about 1 large chile)
4 tablespoons fruity extra virgin olive oil, divided

recipeInstructions.text:
Arrange grapefruit and avocado on four plates. Top with sprinkles of red onion and aji panca. On each plate, drizzle 2 teaspoons reserved grapefruit juice over avocado slices, covering well to prevent browning. Then drizzle 1 tablespoon olive oil over each plate. Add salt, mostly on avocado, to taste, starting with 1/4 teaspoon per plate. Serve immediately. This Recipe Appears In 
 Spice Hunting: Aji Panca

review.reviewBody: I made this without the chile powder (didn't have any). It is great! It was the highlight of the meal.

Fudgefactor: aji panca is in a different chile family. Here's some more information about it. The pasilla/ancho ambiguity is frustrating. Here's my take: anchos are dried poblano chiles, and pasilla negros are dried chilaca chiles (which you'll be hard pressed to find fresh in the States). They work well as substitutes for each other, though pasillas are darker and more intense. By contrast, aji panca is really bright and fruity, but it has a tinge of smokiness in it. But don't let that stop you from making this—most dried chiles would taste great here.

Is aji panca the same as pasilla which is the same as ancho chile? (The pasilla/ancho thing is confusing enough already.)
I hope so, because then I have all these ingredients on hand!
Macartian: pomelo (if you can have it) or blood orange would work well. I'd love to hear what substitutions you try.
Since I can no longer eat grapefruit due to medical reasons (much to my chagrin), I am going to try this with some other citrus. It looks great
